criteria: Understanding of Slope as a Constant Rate of Change
Application of Similar Triangles to Justify Slope
Derivation and Understanding of Linear Equations (y = mx and y = mx + b)
descriptions: Student does not demonstrate an understanding of slope or rate of change.
Student shows a limited understanding of slope as rise over run, but cannot consistently apply it.
Student can calculate slope given a graph or two points, but struggles to explain it as a constant rate of change.
Student understands slope as a constant rate of change and can calculate it accurately.
Student can explain and calculate slope as a constant rate of change and can relate it to real-world contexts.
Student demonstrates a deep understanding of slope as a constant rate of change, can apply it in various contexts, and can explain its significance in linear relationships.
Student does not use or understand similar triangles in the context of slope.
Student attempts to use similar triangles but struggles to connect them to the concept of slope.
Student can identify similar triangles on a line but cannot fully explain how they justify the constant slope.
Student uses similar triangles to explain why the slope is the same between any two points on a line.
Student clearly and accurately uses similar triangles to justify the constant slope and explains the proportional relationship.
Student provides a sophisticated explanation of how similar triangles prove the consistency of slope on a line and extends this understanding to more complex scenarios.
Student does not demonstrate understanding of linear equations or their components.
Student recognizes the equations but cannot explain the meaning of 'm' and 'b'.
Student can identify 'm' as slope and 'b' as y-intercept, but struggles to derive the equations.
Student can derive the equation y = mx for a line through the origin and y = mx + b for a line intercepting the y-axis.
Student clearly derives and explains the meaning of each component (m, b) in the linear equations and relates them to graphical representations.
Student demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of linear equations, can derive them from various starting points, and can explain how changes in 'm' and 'b' affect the line.
